My mum was one of kind as soon as anyone met her they would never forget her. She had a brilliant sense of humour. Her and my dad looked after so many children together. If anyone ever needed help you know my mum would be there always, her front door was always open. She was loved by so many people and as a family it has been lovely hearing people’s memory’s of her. 

Me and my brother couldn’t ask for a better mum, we never went without. She wasn’t just our mum she was our best friend. She has 5 amazing grandchildren and she was the most amazing grandma she loved them all so much. 

Thank you for all your kind words and support. 

Allan, Mike & Vicky xxxxx

story:
Sharp UK are holding a national event in memory of his team-mate Mark Dunn, who sadly passed away in July from cardiac arrest.

The challenge will aim to bring everyone at SBSUK together to hit a collective target of 518 miles - equivalent to over 1 million steps. This would take us from the most Northern office in Dundee to the most Southern in Swanley. The challenge will be monitored and a team total from everyone taking part will be collated via the Challenge Hound and Strava apps.

A fitting tribute 


Dave said: "Mark was a colleague, but he was also a good friend to me and many others at Sharp. When he passed it was a massive shock, and unexpected by his family and everyone that knew him. If you knew Mark,
he was a fit, healthy, and strong. He had a degree in Sports Science from Liverpool University, he played football and was a very active kind of person.

Mark’s family have given their blessing and are delighted that we are doing this in Mark’s memory. 

The British Heart Foundation was the family’s chosen charity, so it’s great we can do something to support a very worthy cause.”

pageSummaryWhat: Complete 1000 miles in 2020 (100 more to go)
story:
Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support, in 2002 Rory was born with a  congenital heart disease, Tetralogy of Fallots, it was a bolt from the blue and literally turned our lives upside down. Even at the turn of this century without pioneering surgery a child with this diagnosis would rarely have made it to its first birthday.

Thanks to British Heart Foundation and ongoing development of their research Rory has had surgery and is still closely monitored, the repairs that are carried out are not lifelong. Rory had an appointment at paediatric cardiology this week and depending on MRI results will now be discharged into the care of adult cardiology, this is a HUGE milestone and without ongoing research just wouldn’t have happened.

I want to give something back so wonder if people will donate to support me running another 100 miles from today before the end of this year meaning I will have run a total of 1006 miles this year. I am not a natural runner as many folk in Kinross who have seen me will probably vouch for!

I would be ever so grateful  and delighted to give back to a cause which has given us so much.

this Christmas!

festive season, and we know you will miss seeing our life-changing doggy volunteers! We’re hoping you will help us and donate to our ‘12 Guide Dogs of Christmas’ Collection as we aim to raise enough for 12 new guide dog partnerships!  

It costs over £56,000 to fund the lifetime cost of a guide dog. Please consider donating £12 during our 12-day collection so we can fund 12 new life-changers this Christmas.

Thank you and Merry Christmas!

story:
As a society we never expect maternity services to be funded by a charity, so why do we expect this for end-of-life care?

This year I'm very excited to be raising £2,700 for Marie Curie in partnership with Choose A Challenge. Marie Curie is an amazing charity that provide care and support to thousands of terminally-ill patients across the UK.

Marie Curie Nurses are working on the front line through this pandemic, providing guidance and emotional support at patients' homes day and night, and Marie Curie's hospices throughout the UK provide essential therapy and inpatient treatment. During this pandemic, Marie Curie's services have struggled more than ever - nurses require PPE to keep providing their quality 24-hour care, and extra support must be given to patients who have tested positive for COVID-19.

With your help, we can keep Marie Curie's action going strong this winter:

• £20 pays for an hour of vital expert care from a Marie Curie Nurse

• £57 pays for an hour of clinical support from an Expert Nurse via support line

• £66 pays for heating an entire Marie Curie hospice for a day (a lifesaver in winter!)

Donate if you can, and also please spread the message by sharing this page around!

charity.name: Unicef UK
story:
I am fundraising because Unicef urgently need funds to expand the scale and scope of their work supporting children affected by coronavirus, especially in countries with weaker health systems.
Just £30 could provide a full kit to protect a health-worker on the frontline, including gloves, masks and coveralls, while just £43 could help provide 1,680 pairs of disposable gloves for health workers.
The impact of a large-scale outbreak of coronavirus on children, especially poor and vulnerable children, has been immense. Children are at risk from the disease, but also from the disruption to health and education services, impacts on caregivers, and separation from family members.
Unicef has been working closely with governments and the World Health Organization (WHO) since the start of the coronavirus outbreak. Donations made to my page will help to limit the spread of the virus and reduce the impact on children and families.

story:
Hello, Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I’m a Swedish artist based in London, I love to make my work and I feel privileged to be able to do so. 

Put simply; I grew up in a family of doctors, understanding how vital good care is, yet I’ve always known I wanted to be an artist and chose that path early on.

I’m often chasing time, lacking the hours in the day to create the work I want to make. But I’m increasingly aware of how my time spent making art doesn’t benefit other people.

In light of this I thought I’d challenge myself to spend much more time in one day making art, sharing it and hopefully engaging others to watch, perhaps join in and most importantly to raise money too.

I will endeavour to live stream my activity (TBC) and I might have to take a 5 min break each hour. I’m hoping it will be fun, intense and that people will enjoy watching it happen however it will turn out.

See you on then and please pass it on!!!

9 AM 22nd November - 9 AM 23 November  (UK time)
